title: I am good at every subject in school except for Math. What should I do to get better at Math, since I feel stupid when I'm doing it? - Quora

response.answer_text: I write extensively on this subject on the math blog for Logic Roots company. Please visit the site for more detailed insights and many other fun math tricks and tips. I am sure they will help you get better at math. The first step to get better at math is to be willing to get better at it and from your question it is clear that you are on the right track. If you want to get better at math then there is a very simple way. Mark my word, I say it is simple but not easy. Practice:To get better at math you need to practice it, and practice it a lot. Math is not a subject where you memorize the concepts.Understand the concepts: The key to math is understanding the concepts. If you don't understand a concept ask your teacher to explain it again. If you still don't get it, then refer internet. The internet is filled with numerous math help articles and math help videos. You may even find tips, tricks and shortcuts to do math operations.Solve more problems: Solve as many problems as you can. Don't hesitate to solve the problems of higher difficulty. Always remember there is no failure in practice. so don't be afraid of going wrong.No distractions:Be focused when you study math, so remember to switch off all distractions while you are practicing math. Study in a clutter-free area. Quench your thirst, and satisfy all your hunger needs before you sit to study math.Play Math Games: Try this novel approach. make math fun by playing math games. You will automatically start taking interest in the subject. Also, while playing math games, brain works in a totally different way and often you tend to understand the concepts you never understood in class.Move on, don't be stuck: If you get stuck at any problem, don't feel discouraged. Move ahead and try solving a different problem and return to the problem after you are able to solve few other problems.Be specific with your doubts: Always be specific about your doubts when you ask questions to your teachers. Don't just say that you didn't understand a concept. Pose your hows and whys in appropriate manner.Learn from your mistakes: Mistakes are the best learning tools; learn from them.Prepare in advance: Whatever lesson a teacher is going to teach in the next class, read about it beforehand. Result will be you would be slightly acquainted with the basics when class starts and as the teacher goes ahead to explain the concept in detail the explanation will get properly percolated into your head leading to better understanding.Make notes and revise: Many of us don't think it is necessary to make notes in math. This is wrong. Make notes during math classes. Jot down those stray caution points that are concealed in your teacher's explanations. Revise your notes while the lecture is still fresh in mind.Finish the math homework first: Most people leave the math homework for the last as they feel too strained to do it. If you want to be better at math then do the math homework while the lesson is still fresh in your mind. This way you will be able to do the math homework much faster than you would if you keep it for last. Also, doing math homework first is a way of tightening the roots of those concepts that have been instilled in your brain.I give you all the above tips because it has worked for me. I hope that you find these tips helpful. All the best.

First, I am glad you feel frustrated about your lack of knowledge in Math and have the desire to improve. Math is a fascinating and useful subject that develops your thinking in the long term, but often it is not very well taught in school. In addition, people that don't have a natural knack on it, give up easily partly because of lack of support. Here are a few pieces of advice I can give you from my personal experience:  Don't give upWork hard and every day without skipping any lesson in school. This is particularly important since concepts in math build on one another. Many people give up after they missed some foundational material.Get the help of a tutorAsk the teacher more questions in classMake a study group with your peers, if you find that there might be other people interestedLastly, I can tell you a little bit about my own experience. As a middle schooler I was pretty good at Math, but I was not an A student. My Math professor was  particularly hard on us, and the only subject I was not getting As in was Math. So I studied hard, everyday, and focused on Math particularly. Fast forward a few years in high school: I started participating in math competitions and did well at a national level. My boyfriend at that time who was a few years older than me, majored in Math and he influenced me as well to major in it. I wound up being a Math major at Princeton and now I'm doing a PhD in Applied Math.  It's so weird to think what would've happened had I been less ambitious at some time in middle school or high school and had given up on Math.
